register as usual and will report to an
advisor. From there he will report to the
room in which there will be representatives of each department with a section
schedule for each course. He will be
assigned to a section in the course he
wishes to take. Each section will be limited to a certain set number of students.
Each department representative to whom
he goes will fit in the course so that no
conflicts will occur. If difficulty does
arise, then the department representatives
concerned will confer immediately in that
room to settle the difficulty. Mr. Dempster will be present, too, to aid in smoothing out any snags that may arise in any
individual case. In plain words, the student will work out his schedule, with his
definite class sections, on the day of registration with the help of the representatives from each undergraduate department.
This should add at least one week to
the actual classroom work and should prevent any inconveniences and disturbances
on the part of both student and instructor.

Pay Hullabaloo!
INFORMATION has been received
by us from Charles Davis, business manager of The Hullabaloo, to the effect that
only those seniors who pay up their class
dues and those organizations which pay
for space in the year book will have their
photographs in the annual.
We agree with the business manager
that this move is a fair one. It is not a
secret by any means that in past years
seniors pulled "fast ones" and managed
to get their photos in the publication. It
is no secret either that certain organizations on the campus haven't paid their
debts owed to the yearbook for the past
two college terms.
The Hullabaloo must have money this
year. It is at present at one of the most
critical points of its existence.
It is unfair to those who pay their class
dues and space fee if the yearbook prints
the photos of those seniors and organizations failing to meet their financial obligations.

JEWS

By MILLARD LANGFELD, JR.
Complete with its original cast, its many
and phenomenally elaborate scenes, its
distinguished company of brilliant stars,
and its large and beautiful singing and
dancing chorus, Of Thee I Sing, which
opens at Ford's Theatre Monday, brings
to Baltimore the finest comic opera production which this city has yet seen.
For forty-five weeks this 1932 Pulitzer
prize winner, headed by the lovely Lois
Moran and the talented William Gaxton
and Victor Moore, played to capacity audiences on Broadway, not only marking
an epoch in musical comedy history, but
presenting a shrewd and pertinent sideline on the political . life of the nation
which will go down in political history.
With the book by Kaufman and Ryskind, and the lyrics and score by the
Gershwins, this is a show that just cannot be missed.
Jiggs Comes To Town
Featuring Danny Simmons, the originator of the role, and one who has played
it from coast to coast for many years,
Bringing Up Father, which will occupy
the boards at the Maryland for the coming week, is a screamingly hilarious farce
built around the adventures of the comic
strip character made famous by George
McManus.
A supporting cast of much note, a
snappy chorus and able direction have
here coimbined to give a show which will
provide three hours of pleasant entertainment.
Horror And How
Acme of the horror pictures and a masterpiece of motion picture art, The Island
Of Lost Souls, which is playing at the
Century Theatre this week, brings to the
screen an enthralling dramatization of
H. G. Well's noted book of the same
name.
Almost too horrible in the vividness of
its action, the film brings such stars as
Bela (Dracula) Lugosi, Richard Arlen,
Charles Laughton, as well as introducing
Kathleen Burke, Paramount's famous
Panther Woman.
Radio's leading stars reign supreme on
the stage, where Jacques Renard and the

Camel Quarter Hour Orchestra, featuring the Eton Boys with Do, Re and Me,
lead an exceptionally fine bill.
China Stars Again
The mazes of San Francisco's Chinatown, its plots, intrigue and tong battles,
and the romance of a Chinese girl who
sells herself at auction to aid her countrymen, furnish the dramatic background
of The Son-Daughter, thrilling adaptation of David Belasco's famous stage play
now current at Loew's Stanley.
With Helen Hayes, the Madelon Clandet of the screen; Lewis Stone, Ramon
Novarro and that greatest of all Oriental
mimics, Warner Oland, The Son-Daughter is a real triumph.
Another Karloff
Headed by the grim figure of Boris
Karloff, who is guaranteed the most terrifying character of the films today, The
Old Dark House, now playing at Keith's,
is a mystery thriller with a brand new
angle. If you like horrors, you'll like
Karloff, and if you like Karloff at his
best, you'll like this show.
Earl Carroll At Hipp
An unusual innovation will mark the
show at the Hippodrome this week, when
for the first time in the history of the
well-known Broadway producer, Earl
Carroll's Vanities will be offered at a
vaudeville or motion picture theatre.
In conjunction with Goldie Gets Along,
starring Lily Damita and Charles Morton, this week's show is, to say the least,
unusual.
The "Emden" Sails Again
Taking as its theme one of the most
glorious pages of German naval history,
Cruiser Emden, which opens at the Europa Monday, marks one of the finest productions the Europa has undertaken to
bring to Baltimore this year.
Following the adventures of this "Old
Ironsides" of German history, the film is
a fascinating one from end to end.
The Sorcerer is making such a success
at the Guild as to merit its being held
over yet another week, and a show worthy
of so many continuations speaks for itself.

A Good Idea
TO SOME, the change in registration
which is to go into effect at the beginning
of the academic term 1933-34 may appear quite minor. In reality, however,
it is an important step forward and is a
solution to a major problem which has
confronted both new and old students each
October.
No one can deny that no less than ten
days are usually lost at the opening of
the University because of the poor system of assigning students to classes. This
is valuable time lost to every student and
to every instructor. The solution to the
problem, it seems, lies in the plans which
Ryland N. Dempster, registrar, has been
instrumental in promulgating.
In the past, the registrar's office drew
up a schedule for all the classes given in
the undergraduate departments, which
was published in the catalog for each
school. Usually the student knows, from
the start, long before registration, what
courses he must and wants to take. He
fills out his own schedule of hours, in
most cases, and shows it to his advisor
when he is assigned to one on the day
of registration. The advisor, generally
okays it, after giving a good pretense of
being much concerned in the welfare of
the undergraduate who is his advisee for
the year.
What happens? The student reports to
class. There he is either told he doesn't
belong there for one or two of ten reasons, or he is told that he must report to
another section of that class. That picture is a familiar one to all undergraduates. The student then chases to his advisor's office to report the matter and to
ask to be straightened out at once. But
he finds that his advisor is not in and
doesn't make a practice of keeping office
hours. Several days pass by before he
finds some means of straightening out the
difficulty. In the meantime, actual class
work has not begun, for the instructors
find it is useless in the turmoil of sectioning courses, making changes, and trying to find more room for overcrowded
classes.
The solution to the situation was simple and yet no move was made until
this year to put it into effect. All that
was necessary was to schedule sections
for each required freshman and sophomore class, especially, and to arrange the
hours of these sections in such a manner
in two groups of days—Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, Friday
and Saturday—so that there would be no
conflicts in the student's required underclass courses. With two required courses
scheduled at the beginning of the week,

ILLUSION:
One of Houdini's most spectacular escape feats
was performed with a huge milk can filled with
water. He invited persons of the audience to bring
padlocks and lock him into the can. He got into the
can, the lid was put on and fastened with several
padlocks. A screen was placed in front of the can.
Assistants stood by with stop watches and fire axes
to save him from drowning after a certain time.
About a minute later, the screen was removed,
Houdini was seen panting and dripping..,the
padlocks remaining intact!
EXPLANATION:
The usual method of escaping from a milk can is
as follows: The lid of the can is apparently securely padlocked to the lower portion, but actually the
metal band to which the staples are attached is the
top of a short inner lining. The performer, after
being locked into the can, pushes the lid upward
with his head and the short inner lining is forced
out of place, permitting his escape. The screen is
then removed.

register as usual and will report to an
advisor. From there he will report to the
room in which there will be representatives of each department with a section
schedule for each course. He will be
assigned to a section in the course he
wishes to take. Each section will be limited to a certain set number of students.
Each department representative to whom
he goes will fit in the course so that no
conflicts will occur. If difficulty does
arise, then the department representatives
concerned will confer immediately in that
room to settle the difficulty. Mr. Dempster will be present, too, to aid in smoothing out any snags that may arise in any
individual case. In plain words, the student will work out his schedule, with his
definite class sections, on the day of registration with the help of the representatives from each undergraduate department.
This should add at least one week to
the actual classroom work and should prevent any inconveniences and disturbances
on the part of both student and instructor.

Pay Hullabaloo!
INFORMATION has been received
by us from Charles Davis, business manager of The Hullabaloo, to the effect that
only those seniors who pay up their class
dues and those organizations which pay
for space in the year book will have their
photographs in the annual.
We agree with the business manager
that this move is a fair one. It is not a
secret by any means that in past years
seniors pulled "fast ones" and managed
to get their photos in the publication. It
is no secret either that certain organizations on the campus haven't paid their
debts owed to the yearbook for the past
two college terms.
The Hullabaloo must have money this
year. It is at present at one of the most
critical points of its existence.
It is unfair to those who pay their class
dues and space fee if the yearbook prints
the photos of those seniors and organizations failing to meet their financial obligations.

JEWS

By MILLARD LANGFELD, JR.
Complete with its original cast, its many
and phenomenally elaborate scenes, its
distinguished company of brilliant stars,
and its large and beautiful singing and
dancing chorus, Of Thee I Sing, which
opens at Ford's Theatre Monday, brings
to Baltimore the finest comic opera production which this city has yet seen.
For forty-five weeks this 1932 Pulitzer
prize winner, headed by the lovely Lois
Moran and the talented William Gaxton
and Victor Moore, played to capacity audiences on Broadway, not only marking
an epoch in musical comedy history, but
presenting a shrewd and pertinent sideline on the political . life of the nation
which will go down in political history.
With the book by Kaufman and Ryskind, and the lyrics and score by the
Gershwins, this is a show that just cannot be missed.
Jiggs Comes To Town
Featuring Danny Simmons, the originator of the role, and one who has played
it from coast to coast for many years,
Bringing Up Father, which will occupy
the boards at the Maryland for the coming week, is a screamingly hilarious farce
built around the adventures of the comic
strip character made famous by George
McManus.
A supporting cast of much note, a
snappy chorus and able direction have
here coimbined to give a show which will
provide three hours of pleasant entertainment.
Horror And How
Acme of the horror pictures and a masterpiece of motion picture art, The Island
Of Lost Souls, which is playing at the
Century Theatre this week, brings to the
screen an enthralling dramatization of
H. G. Well's noted book of the same
name.
Almost too horrible in the vividness of
its action, the film brings such stars as
Bela (Dracula) Lugosi, Richard Arlen,
Charles Laughton, as well as introducing
Kathleen Burke, Paramount's famous
Panther Woman.
Radio's leading stars reign supreme on
the stage, where Jacques Renard and the

Camel Quarter Hour Orchestra, featuring the Eton Boys with Do, Re and Me,
lead an exceptionally fine bill.
China Stars Again
The mazes of San Francisco's Chinatown, its plots, intrigue and tong battles,
and the romance of a Chinese girl who
sells herself at auction to aid her countrymen, furnish the dramatic background
of The Son-Daughter, thrilling adaptation of David Belasco's famous stage play
now current at Loew's Stanley.
With Helen Hayes, the Madelon Clandet of the screen; Lewis Stone, Ramon
Novarro and that greatest of all Oriental
mimics, Warner Oland, The Son-Daughter is a real triumph.
Another Karloff
Headed by the grim figure of Boris
Karloff, who is guaranteed the most terrifying character of the films today, The
Old Dark House, now playing at Keith's,
is a mystery thriller with a brand new
angle. If you like horrors, you'll like
Karloff, and if you like Karloff at his
best, you'll like this show.
Earl Carroll At Hipp
An unusual innovation will mark the
show at the Hippodrome this week, when
for the first time in the history of the
well-known Broadway producer, Earl
Carroll's Vanities will be offered at a
vaudeville or motion picture theatre.
In conjunction with Goldie Gets Along,
starring Lily Damita and Charles Morton, this week's show is, to say the least,
unusual.
The "Emden" Sails Again
Taking as its theme one of the most
glorious pages of German naval history,
Cruiser Emden, which opens at the Europa Monday, marks one of the finest productions the Europa has undertaken to
bring to Baltimore this year.
Following the adventures of this "Old
Ironsides" of German history, the film is
a fascinating one from end to end.
The Sorcerer is making such a success
at the Guild as to merit its being held
over yet another week, and a show worthy
of so many continuations speaks for itself.

A Good Idea
TO SOME, the change in registration
which is to go into effect at the beginning
of the academic term 1933-34 may appear quite minor. In reality, however,
it is an important step forward and is a
solution to a major problem which has
confronted both new and old students each
October.
No one can deny that no less than ten
days are usually lost at the opening of
the University because of the poor system of assigning students to classes. This
is valuable time lost to every student and
to every instructor. The solution to the
problem, it seems, lies in the plans which
Ryland N. Dempster, registrar, has been
instrumental in promulgating.
In the past, the registrar's office drew
up a schedule for all the classes given in
the undergraduate departments, which
was published in the catalog for each
school. Usually the student knows, from
the start, long before registration, what
courses he must and wants to take. He
fills out his own schedule of hours, in
most cases, and shows it to his advisor
when he is assigned to one on the day
of registration. The advisor, generally
okays it, after giving a good pretense of
being much concerned in the welfare of
the undergraduate who is his advisee for
the year.
What happens? The student reports to
class. There he is either told he doesn't
belong there for one or two of ten reasons, or he is told that he must report to
another section of that class. That picture is a familiar one to all undergraduates. The student then chases to his advisor's office to report the matter and to
ask to be straightened out at once. But
he finds that his advisor is not in and
doesn't make a practice of keeping office
hours. Several days pass by before he
finds some means of straightening out the
difficulty. In the meantime, actual class
work has not begun, for the instructors
find it is useless in the turmoil of sectioning courses, making changes, and trying to find more room for overcrowded
classes.
The solution to the situation was simple and yet no move was made until
this year to put it into effect. All that
was necessary was to schedule sections
for each required freshman and sophomore class, especially, and to arrange the
hours of these sections in such a manner
in two groups of days—Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, Friday
and Saturday—so that there would be no
conflicts in the student's required underclass courses. With two required courses
scheduled at the beginning of the week,
either in the morning or the afternoon,
for example, and with two scheduled in
the latter part of the week, the student
could fit in the subjects he is supposed to
take. The courses which most likely will
be sectioned immediately by the registrar are English writing, mathematics,
French, English literature, German, biology, chemistry, physics, freshman and

sophomore history.
Under this new plan the student will

ILLUSION:
One of Houdini's most spectacular escape feats
was performed with a huge milk can filled with
water. He invited persons of the audience to bring
padlocks and lock him into the can. He got into the
can, the lid was put on and fastened with several
padlocks. A screen was placed in front of the can.
Assistants stood by with stop watches and fire axes
to save him from drowning after a certain time.
About a minute later, the screen was removed,
Houdini was seen panting and dripping..,the
padlocks remaining intact!
EXPLANATION:
The usual method of escaping from a milk can is
as follows: The lid of the can is apparently securely padlocked to the lower portion, but actually the
metal band to which the staples are attached is the
top of a short inner lining. The performer, after
being locked into the can, pushes the lid upward
with his head and the short inner lining is forced
out of place, permitting his escape. The screen is
then removed.
